title: Are all of Stephen King's books horror? - Quora

response.answer_text: In fact, no. He’s written five non-fiction books and, of the 61 other books he’s written, several could better be classified as science fiction, fantasy, or even drama. And even his straight horror books often have elements of other genres. King’s never allowed himself to be confined in his storytelling. He frequently mixes genres and themes. The Green Miles, for example, is far more a drama with supernatural elements than it is horror. Although horrific thing do happen in the novel. The Eyes of the Dragon is almost straight fantasy, with some slight tinges of horror here and there. Point being, while King’s reputation is well-established as a horror author, he has much more to offer than just that.

No. He’s always written non-horror books and stories. What I think of as his finest short story and even his finest work period , “The Last Rung on The Ladder” has no supernatural elements at all. “Joyland” has a blink and you’ll miss it supernatural presence but is really more of a coming of age story.”
Not all, no. He wrote some interesting short stories not using super natural nor fantasy themes.

No. He has written books in several different genres, and in that way is one of the most versatile authors currently writing. Two of his non-horror novels are The girl who loved Tom Gordon and Dolores Claiborne.
I know he’s written some nonfiction. His book on writing is titled “On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft”. It may talk about writing horror, but it isn’t horror.
Going to say no. I have not read many. But I intend to read more. The green mile is not horror in my opinion.
